did.abstract: Abraham Hayward, English essayist and translator. His many friendships with significant figures in the literary and political circles of Victorian London resulted in this collection of correspondence. The Abraham Hayward Correspondence Files are chiefly comprised of letters addressed to Abraham Hayward by various English writers, politicians and society figures between 1831 and 1884. Among the correspondents represented are: Lord Brougham, lord chancellor; John Wilson Croker, politician and writer; Isaac D'Israeli, writer; W. E. Gladstone, prime minister and author; Letitia Elizabeth Landon, poet; Edward Bulwer-Lytton, writer and politician; Lady Sydney (Owenson) Morgan, novelist and hostess; Count D'Orsay, man of fashion; Samuel Rogers, poet; and William Makepeace Thackeray, novelist. A few items in the Files are letters addressed to recipients other than Hayward, some apparently collected by him as autographs.

bioghist.p: Abraham Hayward was born in 1801 in Wilton, near Salisbury. To study law at the Inner Temple, he moved in 1824 to London, where he remained for the rest of his life. As a member of the London Debating Society, the young Hayward proved his skill for oratory in debates against such opponents as John Stuart Mill. In 1828 he became joint editor of Law Magazine, or, Quarterly Review of Jurisprudence, and was called to the bar in 1832. The following year he published his translation of Goethe's Faust, which earned wide acclaim and made him part of fashionable society both in Germany and at home. Though ought the rest of his life Hayward was a prolific writer of journal articles on various topics. Though he never himself achieved real fame, he counted many celebrities among his friends.

custodhist.p: Now housed in archival sleeves within upright storage boxes, the letters originally came to the Pforzheimer Collection wrapped in ten bundles of roughly one hundred letters per bundle, each tied with pink tape (see picture to right). The significance of the bundled groupings remains unknown, but the arrangement was likely done by Henry E. Carlisle in preparation for his 1886 edition of selected Hayward letters. The original bundle numbers and ordering are recorded in each item's call numbers. The two digits immediately following HWD in the call number represent the original bundle number; the three further digits reflects the ordering within each bundle. Items with a call number stem other than HWD have been separated from the Files and integrated with other Pforzheimer manuscripts. Their original bundle and order numbers are unknown.

scopecontent.p: The majority of the over one-thousand manuscripts included in the Abraham Hayward Correspondence Files are letters addressed to Hayward by various English writers, politicians and socialites from between the years 1831 and 1884. While they constituted a portion of the materials used to produce Henry E. Carlisle's 1886 Selection from the Correspondence of Abraham Hayward, only a few letters from the Pforzheimer Collection's Hayward Files were included in that publication; most letters remain unpublished.

As the Pforzheimer Collection is primarily a repository for Romantic studies, the Hayward Files were originally of interest to the Pforzheimer Collection for the one letter contained in them by Mary Shelley. For Victorian scholars, however, the Hayward Files provide a substantial resource for research in politics, publishing and fashionable society life. Among the diverse correspondents represented are: Lord Brougham, lord chancellor; John Wilson Croker, politician and writer; Isaac D'Israeli, writer; W. E. Gladstone, prime minister and author; Letitia Elizabeth Landon, poet; Edward Bulwer-Lytton, writer and politician; Lady Morgan, novelist and hostess; Count D'Orsay, man of fashion; Samuel Rogers, poet; and William Makepeace Thackeray, novelist. A few items in the Files are letters addressed to recipients other than Hayward, some apparently collected by him as autographs.

prefercite.p: Abraham Hayward correspondence files : 1063 items, Carl H. Pforzheimer Collection of Shelley and His Circle, The New York Public Library

relatedmaterial.p: In addition to the Abraham Hayward Correspondence Files, the Pforzheimer Collection also holds a copy of a memo from Lady Byron to Harriet Beecher Stowe, in Hayward's hand, on the Byron marriage and separation (B'ANA 0061); and a letter from Hayward to the novelist Jane Porter. For further details on these holdings, see the catalog record for the Abraham Hayward Manuscript Material.

Also held is Hayward's personal bound volume collecting articles written by himself, clipped from the Quarterly Review and the Edinburgh Review. The table of contents is written in ink, in Hayward's hand. Other Hayward-related printed materials held by the Pforzheimer Collection include the 1890 Sotheby catalog of his library; a copy of the first (1858) edition of his Biographical and Critical Essays; his 1870 article for the Quarterly Review on Harriet Beecher Stowe's Lady Byron Vindicated; his 1880 Sketches of Eminent Statesmen; and Henry E. Carlisle's 1886 Selection from the Correspondence of Abraham Hayward.
